intro: Salvia laxispicata, commonly known as the narrow-leaved sage, is a perennial herb native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its slender, upright stems and narrow, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. The plant produces spikes of violet to purple flowers, which bloom in late spring to early summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and full sun, making it a hardy plant suitable for xeriscaping. Its aromatic foliage and ornamental flowers make it a popular choice for gardens and landscapes.
